node.text: @epochwines winemaker discusses Paso Robles, sub appellations, putting history back together, visual tasting notes and pizza toppings

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on September 05, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Can you identify a wine just by reading its tasting note? Put your knowledge to the test with our latest mystery pick, a structured red offering explosively fruity aromas and dark fruit flavors with accents of chocolate, mocha and spice.⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio to see the full tasting note and play this week's edition of What Am I Tasting!⁠
⁠
⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: Alex Treadway/Getty Images⁠
⁠
#winespectator #wine #whatamitasting #blindtasting

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on September 04, 2021.

node.text:
Today’s forward-thinking Spanish winemakers are focused on rediscovery. They're looking inward at the country’s winegrowing past, relying on historic grapes, lands and practices to set their wines apart. ⁠
⁠
Since our last Spain report in October 2020, more than 775 wines have been reviewed in blind tastings, showing impressive quality across the board. With approximately 40% of the total earning outstanding scores of 90 points or higher on Wine Spectator’s 100-point scale and a median price of only $25, it’s clear that the value of Spanish wine is tough to beat.⁠
⁠
Wine Spectator website members can click the linkin.bio for the full tasting report from our Oct. 15 issue that's about to hit newsstands.⁠
⁠
📸: Courtesy of @llopart1887⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #spain #spanishwine #harvest #vineyard

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on September 03, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

node.text:
Is there any more summery combo than tomatoes and corn? Just in time for Labor Day weekend, the two iconic ingredients join forces in this recipe from @davidkinch, the celebrated Bay Area chef behind @manresarestaurant.⁠
⁠
It’s a salad of sorts, but one that’s more interesting than that label implies, juxtaposing cool, raw tomatoes and warm, creamy corn. Some version of the dish has been on all of Kinch's restaurants' menus at one point or another, and it's also featured in his latest cookbook, At Home in the Kitchen.⁠
⁠
Click the linkin.bio to get the chef's recipe for this side dish as well as a garlic and ginger grilled chicken to serve alongside. Plus, see recommendations for fresh and bright white and red wines from Italy to pair with the feast.⁠
⁠
⁠📸: © Aya Brackett⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #recipes #wineandfood #summer #bayarea #tomato #corn #laborday

Seña 2019, released worldwide today, celebrates the 25th Anniversary commemorating the inspiring journey since the first seeds of the project were planted. This 2019 vintage showcases the full potential of Seña in a wine of extraordinary balance, depth and elegance. #sponsored

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on September 02, 2021. May be an image of bottle.
Photo by Wine Spectator on September 02, 2021. May be an image of mountain and nature.
Photo by Wine Spectator in Lewis Cellars with @lewiscellars. May be an image of tree and outdoors.

node.text:
EXCLUSIVE: Paso Robles-based @justinwine is acquiring Napa's @lewiscellars. Owned by a large farming firm that includes brands like Fiji Water and Pom Wonderful, Justin will provide a marketing and sales arm to the brand. Lewis Cellars' co-founder Randy Lewis and president Dennis Bell will remain at the helm of operations, along with winemaker James McCeney.⁠
⁠
"Randy and I have been seeking a compatible partner to maintain the quality and consistency of our wines while taking Lewis Cellars to the next level," Bell told Wine Spectator. "We've found that partner with Justin."⁠
⁠
Read more about these two California wineries joining forces at our link in bio.⁠
⁠
📸: Courtesy of @lewiscellars⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #winenews #pasorobles #napa #california #californiawine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Wine Spectator on August 31, 2021 tagging @bonafideproductions. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Wrapping up our August series of harvest images with this moment of zen.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This picker definitely has the benefit of some extra personal space while working in the Erdener Treppchen vineyard in Germany's Mosel Valley. Another reminder of how quietly beautiful vineyards and harvest work can be.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It's also the last image in our August #WSfeaturedphotographer series featuring the work of Leigh-Ann Beverley.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you're a photog specializing in wine imagery and would like to be one of our featured photogs in the future, send us a message here and we'll get in touch.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In the meantime, cheers to all the intrepid grape pickers and other winery laborers out there. They help to bottle sunshine in a glass, to paraphrase an expression, and we appreciate them for it.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Maule, Chile with @bonafideproductions. May be a black-and-white image of child, standing, indoor and brick wall.

node.text:
Stomping into another week of harvest...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At González Bastías winery in the Maule Valley of Chile, everything is done by hand and without machine, from farming to vinifying. And when it comes to crushing those grapes, these ladies do it in rhythm too.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
(The platform they are standing on is made of bamboo and called a zaranda, with the juice flowing down through it directly into a fermenting vat.)⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Another cool image captured by our #WSfeaturedphotographer Leigh-Ann Beverley, who's been giving us a peek into the harvest work that most folks don't get to see.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to your Monday!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Wine Spectator on August 29, 2021 tagging @knobcreek, and @basilhayden. May be an image of drink and text.

node.text:
Learn how the charring and toasting of oak barrels affects different whiskeys along with Adam Harris, Senior Ambassador of American Whiskey at Beam Suntory. View the tasting at the link in our bio. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#6ourbon7ime #virtualwhiskeytastings #sponsored

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Dry Creek Valley AVA with @bonafideproductions. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
As we head into the waning days of summer we continue to celebrate the faces of harvest work with our #WSfeaturedphotographer, Leigh-Ann Beverley. She captured this image at dawn in Ridge's vineyards located in the Dry Creek Valley.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Harvesting is typically done before daybreak (and sometimes at night) to avoid the heat of the day to bring in the fruit in as fresh a condition as possible. And it's done by hand.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just a reminder that more gets done before 9 a.m. for your bottle of wine than gets done all day...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to the harvesters!⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Portugal's Douro Valley is the home of Port, one of the world's great dessert wines. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you survived Y2K and loaded up on the 2000s upon release, you'll want to know how the wines are doing. Senior Editor @jmolesworth1 has written up his analysis based on a retrospective tasting of the vintage.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you didn't stock up on 2000s back then, well don't worry. Port is also arguably the greatest value in world class, age worthy wines. Older vintages on the secondary market often sell for less than the current releases.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for the full scoop on one of Port's great vintages that is now hitting its stride.⁠⁠
